required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018

clinical_study.brief_title: Acceptance and Efficacy of Live Supervision
clinical_study.official_title: Live Supervision Put to Test - Studies of Acceptance and Efficacy of Computer-assisted Live Supervision

collaborator.agency: Central Institute of Mental Health, Mannheim

brief_summary.textblock: In order to meet an existing lack of empirical studies in the field of cognitive behavioral therapy supervision, the present randomized controlled trial is aimed at comparing two different types of supervision. This study compares computer-assisted live supervision and delayed video-based supervision regarding efficacy and acceptance among therapists, patients and supervisors. The efficacy of supervision is defined on different levels such as change of psychotherapeutic competence, nondisclosure, self-efficacy, self-awareness of the supervisee as well as therapeutic alliance, supervisory alliance and therapy outcome.

primary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
primary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses nondisclosure of the supervisee during supervision

primary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
primary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses self awareness, motivation and dependency- autonomy of supervisees

primary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
primary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses self efficacy of the supervisee

primary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
primary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses level of development and supervision needs of the therapist

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses the therapeutic alliance

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses the supervisory relationship

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses depressive symptoms

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: self-report measure that asessses anxiety symptoms

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses aspects of general psychopathology

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses the health-related quality of life

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses satisfaction with therapy

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: self-report measure that assesses satisfaction with supervision

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of psychotherapy, an expected average of 30 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: clinician-rated measure that assesses psychotherapeutic competencies

arm_group.description: Supervisees assigned to this group will receive 8 sessions of computer-assisted live supervision and 4 sessions of delayed video-based supervision while treating 2 patients during 26 therapy sessions each. Computer-assisted live supervision is also known as "bug-in-the-eye" (BITE) supervision. The supervisor observes the therapy session with the help of a webcam and types messages on his computer. The instructions to the supervisee appear on a second monitor located in the therapy room where the supervisee can view it whenever he wants to.

Supervisees assigned to this group will receive 12 sessions of delayed video-based supervision while treating 2 patients during 26 therapy sessions each. During delayed video-based supervision the supervisor and the supervisee spend 50 minutes reviewing selected parts of video recorded therapy sessions and discussing the case.

intervention.description: 8 BITE sessions, 4 video-based sessions (each 50 minutes) during treatment of 2 patients
12 video-based sessions (each 50 minutes) during treatment of 2 patients

criteria.textblock:
Supervisees
Inclusion Criteria:
- Having successfully completed the interim audit
- Having started to treat ambulant patients under supervision
Exclusion Criteria:
Patients
Inclusion Criteria:
- Meeting ICD 10 criteria for a mental disorder
- Informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Currently in psychotherapy
- Suicidal tendency
- Clinical diagnosis of alcohol or drug addiction, acute schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder or bipolar disorder

facility.name: Department of Clinical Psychology and Psychotherapy of the Wolfgang Goethe University
